questions.text: Which of the following diseases can be spread by the mosquito, as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Filariasis

Explanation:

The above image shows a Culex mosquito, which spreads filariasis.

Gross features of adult mosquitoes:

ANOPHELES

CULEX

AEDES

MANSONOIDES

Rest: angled inclination to surface

Rest: Hunchback position

Rest: hunchback position

Rest: squatting position

Wings spotted

No white stripes

White stripes all over the body

White spots on legs

Both sexes: long palpi

Short palpi in females

Malaria

Japanese

encephalitis,

Filariasis, West

Nile fever

Dengue,

Chikungunya, Rift

valley fever, Zika

virus, Yellow fever

Brugian filariasis
 

Flight range - 10 kms.

Flight range - 100-200 mts

  

 

Culex Anopheles
culex " data-author="US Centers for Disease Control - City of Jacksonville, FL" data-hash="247" data-license="Open access" data-source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culex#/media/File:CPipFm.jpg" data-tags="November2024" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/RmHmaqKj0mV2T7kbswZ11732722021.png" />

questions.text: Identify the genus of the mosquito, the eggs of which are collected from the water source of a street and subjected to microscopic examination as given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anopheles

Explanation:

The above image shows the eggs of an Anopheles mosquito (boat-shaped with lateral floats).

 

ANOPHELES

CULEX

AEDES

MANSONOIDES

EGGS
  • Lays singly
  • Boat shaped
  • Lateral floats

Lays in clusters (100-250 in a single cluster)
  • Lays singly
  • Cigar shaped
  • Lays in clusters
  • Star-shaped

LARVAE
  • No siphon tube
  • Rests parallel to water surface
  • Longer siphon tubes
  • Rests at an angle to water surface
  • Shorter siphon tubes
  • Rests at an angle to water surface

HABITAT

Exophilic: outside house

Clean stagnant water

Anopheles known as a sophisticated mosquito

Exophilic: day

Endophilic: night

Dirty polluted water (ponds)

Endophilic: inside house

Artificial Collected water

Exophilic- Aquatic vegetation (Pistia plants)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male from Bihar, India, presents with a 3-month history of intermittent fever, significant weight loss, and enlargement of the spleen and liver. Physical examination reveals darkening of his skin on the face and extremities. He was bitten by the organism given in the image below. What is the disease and the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Visceral leishmaniasis - sandfly

Explanation:

Leishmaniasis:

  • Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania.
  • Transmitted through the bite of infected sandflies(Phlebotomus argentipes) during blood feeding.
  • Types of Leishmaniasis: Visceral (kala-azar), cutaneous, and mucocutaneous forms
  • Drug of choice - LAMB ( Liposomal Amphotericin B)

Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL or Kala-azar)By L. donovani
  • Irregular bouts of fever, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, anaemia, and weight loss.
  • Family history is common
  • Darkening of skin on the face, hands, feet, and abdomen.

Cutaneous Leishmaniasis

Cutaneous leishmaniasis aka Oriental sore caused By L.tropica
  • Results in skin lesions, mainly ulcers, on exposed body parts.
  • Leaves lifelong scars

Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis

By L.braziliensis
  • Destroys mucous membranes of the nose, mouth, and throat.
  • It can cause severe facial disfigurement and social stigma.

Sandfly:

  • Insects smaller than mosquitoes
  • Brown in color
  • Hairy body
  • Hops around

questions.text: Given below is the image of a parasite. From the options pick a disease that is not transmitted by it.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Oriental sore

Explanation:

The parasite given in the image is a louse. Oriental sore is transmitted by sandflies, and lice transmit the rest.

Lice:

Types of Lice
  • Head louse (Pediculus capitis)
  • Body louse (Pediculus corporis)
  • Pubic or crab louse (Phthirus pubis)

Transmission
  • Direct contact with infested persons.
  • Indirect contact through clothing, bedding, combs, or brushes.
  • Lice can be blown by wind from heavily infested individuals.

Diseases Transmitted
  • Epidemic typhus (caused by Rickettsia prowazekii)
  • Epidemic relapsing fever (caused by Borrelia recurrentis)
  • Trench fever (caused by Rickettsia quintana)
  • Dermatitis due to scratching and secondary infection.

Control Measures
  • Malathion
  • Personal hygiene
  • Mass delousing

Correct Answer: D) Endemic typhus

Explanation:

Fleas

Morphology

Small bilaterally compressed, wingless insects covered with backwardly directed bristles.

Diseases transmitted
  • Plague (bubonic)
  • Endemic or murine typhus
  • Chiggerosis
  • Hymenolepis diminuta

Importance in Public Health

Rat fleas are significant vectors of plague and typhus.

Control measures
  • DDT, gamma-HCH, dieldrin, carbaryl, diazinon, or malathion
  • Diethyltoluamide (DEET) and benzyl benzoate
  • Rodent control
  • Epidemic relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia recurrentis (Option A)
  • Trench fever is caused by Rickettsia quintana (Option B)
  • Epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the parasite shown in the image

choices.text: Ornithodorus moubata is an important species of this parasite

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D : Cannot stand starvation

Explanation:

The image is of a hard tick.

Feature

Hard Ticks (Ixodidae)

Soft Ticks (Argasidae)

Scutum

Covers the entire back in males; only a small portion in front in females

Absent

Head

Situated at the anterior end

Lies ventrally; not seen from above

Habits

Cannot stand starvation; feed night and day

Can stand starvation for a year or more

Diseases transmitted

Tick typhus, Viral encephalitis, Haemorrhagic fever, Tularaemia, Tick paralysis, Human babesiosis

Relapsing fever

Important species

Dermacentor andersoni Haemophysalis spinigera

Ornithodorus moubata

Image

Incorrect options

Ornithodorus moubata is an important species of this parasite (Option A):  Ornithodoros moubata is a soft tick, not a hard tick. It belongs to Argasidae, not Ixodidae. Therefore, it is not a species related to hard ticks.

Transmits relapsing fever (Option B): Incorrect because relpasing fever is transmitted by soft tick (like Argasidae) . Not hard ticks

Has 5 years of nymphal stage (Option C):  Hard ticks can live for several years, but a 5-year-long nymphal stage is not typical. Nymphal stages in ticks generally last weeks to months, sometimes up to a year, depending on the species and environment. 5 years is an exaggeration and not a standard developmental duration

questions.text: A 35-year-old hiker presents with sudden onset fever, severe headache, and a macular rash that appeared around the 5th day of illness. On examination, there is generalised lymphadenopathy and an eschar on his abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Scrub Typhus

Explanation:

Clinical features given in the scenario are of Scrub Typhus.

Trombiculid mite

Scrub Typhus:

Causative bacteria

Orienta (Rickettsia) tsutsugamushi

Transmission

Trombiculid mite

Clinical Features:
  • Acute onset with high fever (104°-105°F), chills, severe headache, malaise, and prostration.
  • A macular rash appears around the 5th day of illness.
  • Generalised lymphadenopathy and lymphocytosis are common.
  • The presence of an eschar (punched-out ulcer with a blackened scab) at the site of the mite bite is characteristic.

Diagnostic Test

Weil-Felix reaction (Heterophile antigen-antibody reaction)

Treatment

Tetracycline

Prophylaxis

Impregnating clothes and blankets with miticidal chemicals (e.g., benzyl benzoate) and mite repellents (e.g., diethyltoluamide) on exposed skin surfaces.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe itching, particularly worse at night, and skin lesions on her hands and wrists. On examination, there are follicular lesions and evidence of secondary infection with crusted papules and pustules. She reports that her husband and children also have similar symptoms. Which of the following is used exclusively as a preventive measure against this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Use of chlordane

Explanation:

Given is a scenario of scabies. Chlordane is used as a preventive measure, and rest is used as a treatment measure.

Sarcoptes scabiei

           

Scabies:

Causative Agent

Sarcoptes scabiei, an arthropod known as the itch mite.

Transmission

Close contact with an infected person or contaminated clothing and bedding.

Clinical Features

  • Severe itching, especially at night.
  • Follicular lesions, crusted papules, and pustules.
  • It commonly affects hands, wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, lower abdomen, feet, and genitals.

Diagnosis
  • Itching worse at night is a key symptom.
  • Examination reveals characteristic lesions.
  • Confirmation by identifying mites or eggs in skin scrapings.

Treatment
  • Benzyl Benzoate- Applied thoroughly to the entire body below the chin, including the soles of feet, and repeated after 12 hours.
  • Gamma-HCH (Lindane)
  • Tetmosol
  • Sulfur Ointment

Preventive Measures

  • Insecticidal Control
    • Effective insecticides: DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, toxaphene.
  • Environmental Control
    • Fill cracks and crevices near buildings and paths. Reduce wild rodents and dogs.
  • Protection of Workers
    • Wear protective clothing with insect repellents (indalone, diethyltoluamide, benzyl benzoate).
    • Regularly check for and remove ticks during breaks, and after work, remove ticks by painting them with petrol or paraffin and brushing them off.
    • If necessary, extract with forceps, avoiding breaking mouthparts.

questions.text: The image of a fly is given below. Which disease does it transmit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sleeping sickness

Explanation:

The insect given in the image is the Tsetse fly, it is a vector of trypanosomiasis/sleeping sickness.

Tsetse fly:

Synonym

Glossina

Location

African continent

Morphology

Resembles houseflies

Yellow/dark brown

Half an inch long

Health impact

Vectors for trypanosomiasis, causing "sleeping sickness”

Control measures

1. DDT and dieldrin

2. Removing vegetation where tsetse flies breed

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is complaining of heart palpitations, nausea, and facial flushing after being bitten by the insect shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chagas disease.

 

Explanation:

  • The image is of the Reduviid bug, and the disease transmitted is Chagas disease.

Reduviid bug:

Synonyms
  • Cone-nose bugs

Location
  • Mexico, Central America, and South America

Morphology
  • An inch or more in length
  • Adults have wings

Feeding

  • Exclusively on the blood

Habitat
  • Cracks, fissures, and other hiding places in walls, ceilings, and animal habitations

Health impact
  • Transmit Trypanosoma cruzi [a protozoa], the causative agent of Chagas' disease, causes intense itching, nausea, flushed face, and palpitations of the heart.

Control measures
  • Insecticides like HCH or dieldrin

 

Scrub typhus (Option B): Incorrect because it is transmitted by chiggers (larval mites), not Reduviid bugs.

Tularaemia (Option C): Incorrect because it is transmitted by ticks, deer flies, or direct contact with infected animals, not Reduviid bugs.

Sleeping sickness (Option D): Incorrect because it is transmitted by tsetse flies (Glossina species), not Reduviid bugs.

questions.text: Mr. Smith, a 50-year-old farmer from rural Africa, presents with severe itching and a "leopard skin" appearance on his legs. He complains of worsening vision with photophobia and conjunctivitis. Examination reveals papular dermatitis, skin depigmentation, and early signs of corneal scarring. He gives a history of being bitten by a fly given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Onchocerciasis

Explanation:

The insect in the image is a black fly, the disease transmitted is Onchocerciasis [river blindness].

Black fly:

Synonyms

Simuliidae.

Morphology

Small with short legs and proboscis and large, broad wings

Black in colour.

Health impact

Bloodsucking and causes river blindness (onchocerciasis).

In contrast - loiasis doesn't cause vision loss , it is present in subconjunctival tissues. (Option C)

Control measures

Abate

Onchocerciasis symptoms:

  • Skin Manifestations:
    • Recurrent severe pruritus
    • Papular dermatitis
    • Lichenified dermatitis
    • Areas of skin depigmentation, especially around the shins, lead to the characteristic "leopard skin" appearance.
  • Ocular Manifestations:
    • Recurrent conjunctivitis
    • Punctate keratitis
    • Photophobia
    • Progressive visual loss.
  • Drug Of Choice - Ivermectin

questions.text: All of the following are transmitted by houseflies except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tularaemia

Explanation:

Tularaemia is transmitted by hard ticks.

Diseases transmitted by houseflies:

  • Systemic infections like typhoid fever and paratyphoid fever.
  • Eye infections such as conjunctivitis and trachoma.
  • Skin infections, including anthrax and yaws.
  • Parasitic diseases like helminthic infestations.
  • Viral infections such as poliomyelitis.
